awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: External Obliviousness in Trusted Execution Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Processing personal data in "the cloud" is an increasingly common computing application. For example, health monitors collect heartbeat data and upload to cloud for personal healthcare and wellbeing. This increases privacy and data security risks. This project aims to achieve provable security in the cloud by protecting data-access patterns in a security-oriented cloud architecture built on the recently released Intel SGX (Software Guard eXtensions) processor. 

The approach of the project is to combine hardware-level protection for strong processor-memory isolation with algorithm-level protection for data-oblivious computing. This new combination, termed external obliviousness, is intended to enable strongly secure computation at a large data scale. The project consists of two thrusts: 1) building externally oblivious programming support for common computation primitives, 2) building externally oblivious software systems for data-analytical queries.

The project will result in multiple broader impacts: The new system-building method of external obliviousness will influence cyber-security and systems research community. The new secure software will potentially expand the cloud industry into supporting security-oriented applications in electronic healthcare. The project will lead to hands-on lab modules integrated with residential curriculum and a nation-wide education platform for both undergraduate students and under-represented groups. 

The project will generate performance-evaluation results from the developed codebase. They will be published to the online repository and be maintained there for 3 years: https://exo-sgx.github.io.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Processing personal data in "the cloud" is an increasingly common computing paradigm. However, leaving sensitive data in the hands of a third-party cloud creates data privacy and security risks. This project tackles protecting the confidentiality and integrity of sensitive data processed in the emerging cloud architecture based on a trusted execution environment (TEE).

In this project, the PI's team has developed software artifacts: software tools that protect TEE against access-pattern side-channel attacks, a data-analytical system that supports various data applications, and a key-value storage system with strong data integrity. Compared with the existing literature, a new methodology is studied when building these systems for side-channel security: dynamic wrapping of execution units for isolated program execution within CPUs. The new software artifacts are shared publicly in open-source websites (e.g., github).

The new software has the potential to impact confidential computing in public cloud services and support new domain applications in medical data processing, healthcare IT hosting, online social networks, etc. Through the project, the PI?s team built hands-on labs on TEE and used them in the courses the PI taught at his home university. The PI has delivered public lectures various circumstances, including local museums, Junior Science Camp, IT professionals, etc. These events are organized by different organizations and reach wide variety of populations such as NSBE (National Society of Black Engineers) and SPHE (Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers). The project outcome has win a series of competitions such as Google & Intel Confidential Computing challenge and iDash competition organized by UCSD. Throughout the project, the PI?s group has graduated 6 undergraduate students and one Ph.D. student who joined another university as as a tenure-track assistant professor.


 

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2023
Modified by: Yuzhe Tang
